awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Reliability as an Emergent Property of Transportation Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate how individual travel behavior (e.g., route choice, trip scheduling, and selection of transportation mode) and transportation-related organizational decision-making (e.g., investment and pricing decisions) impact travel reliability (percentage of on-time arrival at destination). This research tests the hypothesis that minor behavior changes at the individual or organizational level leads to significant changes in travel reliability. The theory explains how individuals and organizations actually make transportation-related decisions, recognizing that they do not have perfect information or unlimited computational capabilities. The empirical portion of the research addresses a gap in the transportation science literature by employing smart phones as mobile GPS sensors to collect travel behavior data.

If successful, this project will provide decision-support tools that could help transform transportation systems operations and planning practices. These tools will enable transportation agencies to assess strategies that induce individual and organizational behavioral changes (e.g., increased transit ridership, improved trip departure time choice, better route diversion decisions, and more cost-effective transportation investments) that could mitigate traffic congestion and improve travel reliability. Over the long run, a more efficient and reliable transportation system will stimulate economic growth, enhance quality of life, and support emergency response. As this research breaks traditional disciplinary boundaries between the behavioral sciences and systems engineering, it also sets the stage for a new research direction that focuses on optimizing transportation system performance based on how choices are actually made, not how they should be made. This project will involve high school undergraduate, and graduate underrepresented students in various research tasks. Research findings will be broadly distributed through a K-12 Transportation Education Web Portal, an open-access Wiki site, and other professional and community outreach efforts.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this CAREER project are to account for emergent properties of transportation network reliability, measure actual individual and organizational behavior in transportation systems with high accuracy levels and for long-periods of time, apply descriptive behavior theory to transportation systems optimization, and test the hypothesis that significant network reliability improvement can be accomplished with small feasible micro-level behavior shifts.

 

To achieve these objectives, the project PI has completed the following research tasks: (1) Theorize individual travel decision-making without assuming substantial rationality, and apply the descriptive theory to model route, departure time, mode, and destination choices under uncertainty with behavioral process data collected from mobile GPS sensors; (2) Measure and model organizational pricing and investment behavior based on observed decision outcomes and knowledge extraction methods; (3) Simulate interdependent individual and organizational behavior dynamics with agent-based methods and measure macro-level network reliability as an emergency property; and (4) Enable systematic discovery of feasible behavior shifts that most significantly enhance network reliability by developing an innovative systems optimization approach that integrates descriptive behavior research and normative optimization objectives.

 

Under this CAREER project, more than 50 technical papers are published in leading transportation journals, such as Transportation Research and Transportation Science. Research findings are also presented at more than 10 national and international conferences, such as Transportation Research Board Annual Meeting, International Symposium on Transportation Network Reliability, and INFORMS Joint International Conference. The project PI has mentored three postdoctoral researchers and five graduate students who full-time work on or partially participate in the project. Two doctoral students (Chenfeng Xiong and Xiang He) partially funded by this project have completed their PhD studies. The P.I. teaches four courses, namely Introduction to Transportation Engineering and Planning, OR Models in Transportation Systems Analysis, Transportation Economics, and Sustainable Transportation, in the Transportation Engineering Program of the University of Maryland, College Park. The agent based modeling theory has been incorporated into these courses. In addition, multiple training seminars (e.g, on DTA Lite) and conferences (e.g., 2014 World Symposium on Transport and Land Use Research) have been organized under this project.

 

Regarding Intellectual Merit, this project transforms transportation systems complexity research by accurately measuring the impact of both individual and organizational behavior on network reliability and systematically discovering attainable behavior shifts with significant system-wide benefits. The theoretical research replaces unrealistic assumptions of perfect rationality with verifiable actual behavioral mechanisms, recognizing the importance of learning, behavioral adaption, and evolution in travel behavior. The empirical research strives to eliminate critical constraints in network complexity analysis such as the lack of reliable individual behavioral process data and poor understanding of organizational behavior. In particular, this project is one of the first studies that employ smart phones as mobile GPS sensors for descriptive behavior research and planning-level systems optimization. Also for the first time, the long-term network reliability impact of organizational behavior is tested and measured. The outcomes of this research opens up a new avenue for transportation systems research that integrates descriptive behavior analysis and normative systems optimization.

 

Regarding Broader Impact, this project has helped expand the collaboration with local high schools and the University of Maryland (UMD) Women In Engineering Program and Center for Minorities in Science and Engineering by involving underrepresented students in this CAREER project. In addition, an interactive K-12 Transportation Education Web-Based Portal is developed to help teachers and children’s/science museums to engage students in learning the emergence of network congestion and reliability from individual travel decisions. Methods and findings from the CAREER research plan are integrated into existing and new interdisciplinary courses for further research-education integration. The PI develops open-access wiki sites and organizes workshops/tutorials on transportation systems complexity to maximize the research impact among transportation professionals. This CAREER project also has broad societal and economic impacts by potentially transforming transportation systems operations and planning practices with decision-support and systems optimization tools based on descriptive behavior analysis. Agencies can apply research findings to design feasible strategies inducing individual/organizational behavior changes that mitigate congestion and improve reliability during recurrent and non-recurrent travel conditions.
